p: The Royle's pika inhabits rock crevices in talus fields with a home range of approximately 50 m 2 (Bhattacharyya et al., 2015; Kawamichi, 1968). During 2014–2015, 104 rock talus habitats were surveyed and faecal pellets collected from five sites at elevations ranging between 2,600 and 4,450 m above sea level (a.s.l.): Chopta‐Tungnath (TUN), Rudranath (RUD), Madmaheshwar (MAD: Kedarnath Wildlife Sanctuary), Har ki Doon (HAR: Govind Wildlife Sanctuary) and Bedni‐Roopkund (NAN: Nandadevi Biosphere Reserve; Figure 1) in Garhwal, Uttarakhand, India. The sampling was conducted in two seasons: postmonsoon (October to November 2014) in TUN, RUD and HAK and premonsoon (May to June 2015) in TUN, MAD and NAN.
